numbered_ace_sentences: 1. I notice a boost for legacy applicants of any kind.
2. This boost is about 2 times.
3. The legacy line stays constantly above the non-legacy line.
4. I notice that extremely wealthy legacy applicants are nearly 7 times more likely to be accepted.
5. Extremely wealthy legacy applicants are the top 0.1 percentile.
6. Elite colleges have an acceptance rate of about 3.3% to 7.3%.
7. The acceptance rate for rich legacy applicants is about 23.1% to 51.1%.
8. This fact is important.
9. Traditionally, people who go to elite colleges are more likely to be rich in the future.
10. The boost for wealthy applicants is meant to keep the class divide obvious.
11. The boost for legacy applicants is meant to keep the school selective.
12. I wonder if the legacy boost exists in every college.
13. Each college could have an individual graph.
14. An individual graph could plot the difference between legacy applicants and non-legacy applicants.
15. I ask if this bias affects other things at the college.
16. I ask if this bias affects grades.
17. I ask if this bias affects clubs.
18. I notice a dip in the graph around the 50th percentile.
19. I notice a dip in the graph below the 90th percentile.
20. I ask why this dip exists.
21. I ask what makes top 0.1 percentile legacy applicants attractive to colleges.
22. This topic relates to me and my community.
23. I plan to go to college one day.
24. I am a middle-class non-legacy applicant.
25. It feels discouraging for me to apply to Ivy League schools.
26. It feels discouraging for me to apply to other elite schools.
27. If I get accepted into these schools then many other students will be extremely wealthy.
28. This situation can lead to a difference in experience.
29. This situation can lead to a difference in values.
30. The headline is: Are you rich?
31. The headline is: Are you a legacy?
32. The headline is: Welcome to Harvard!
